comment.author: 61603688@N03
comment._content: Being a drummer was actually pretty dangerous. They conveyed the orders to the soldiers, so the enemy would try to pick them off so nobody would know what they were supposed to be doing. He may also have been an ammuntion runner (I know there's another term, but it escapes me) carrying powder and shot to soldiers up and down the lines.

comment.author: 48165107@N04
comment._content: Thank you for that piece of information, Lady AnneJT! I had no idea they had such a dangerous task, what a heavy burden on one so young!

comment.author: 8096523@N05
comment._content: I think the term is powder monkey.

comment.author: 61699134@N02
comment._content: Powder monkeys were sailors. Young drummer boys were typically kept out of the front lines and were generally protected to the extent possible. They also as stretcher bearers and medical assistants to the surgeons.  My great grandfather was a 14 year old bandsmen in a Wisconsin regiment and this was mentioned in some of his correspondence.

comment.author: 8913547@N06
comment._content: Boys this young did fight. The youngest recorded child wounded in battle was 12.

comment.author: 21556439@N04
comment._content: With the rise of tintype photography, came purveyors of novelty portraits who would set up shop at the state fair or the county fair.  Could it be that some of these very young "soldiers" were sporting uniforms and weapons as theatrical props for a novelty portrait?
